headline: Georgia Power says it needs a huge increase in power capacity to meet data center demand
summary: With data centers flooding into Georgia, utility regulators face a big decision: Should they let Georgia Power Co. spend more than $15 billion to increase its electricity capacity by 50% over the next six years to serve computer complexes?  It would be one of the biggest build-outs in the U.S. to meet the insatiable electricity demand from developers of artificial intelligence.  The largest subsidiary of Atlanta-based Southern Co., Georgia Power said in testimony filed last month that the build-out will boost the state's economy and “allow Georgia to contribute to the nation’s focus on the global importance of artificial intelligence and the digital economy.”

The largest subsidiary of Atlanta-based Southern Co., Georgia Power said in testimony filed last month that the build-out will boost the state's economy and “allow Georgia to contribute to the nation’s focus on the global importance of artificial intelligence and the digital economy.”

headline: CEG Outpaces Its Industry in the Past Month: How to Play the Stock?
summary: CEG stock has outperformed peers with strong clean-energy momentum, a low debt load and rising earnings estimates.

headline: How Duke’s Advanced Nuclear and Storage Pivot Could Reshape the Investment Case for Duke Energy (DUK)
summary: Duke Energy has reaffirmed its role in a US Department of Energy cost-share project backing GE Vernova Hitachi’s BWRX-300 small modular reactor technology and is preparing an early site permit application for potential SMR deployment at its Belews Creek, North Carolina site by the end of 2025. Together with its expanding energy storage plans, this advanced nuclear push highlights how Duke is trying to pair grid reliability with lower-carbon power over the long term. We’ll now explore how...

headline: After Neuralink, Max Hodak is building something even wilder
summary: "You could really, in a very fundamental sense, talk about redrawing the border around a brain," Hodak says, "possibly to include four hemispheres, or a device, or a whole group of people."

raw.headline: After Neuralink, Max Hodak is building something even wilder
